conversations.value: Hey, Point Break, check out this photo. This dude's about to eat it hard. Reminds me of you at the Battle of Xandar, trying to be all fancy with your hammer-throwing moves.
Star-Lord, you jest, but skateboarding was unknown to me before Midgard. This mortal seems quite brave, speeding towards his destiny on four small wheels.
Brave? More like totally gnarly. You think you could handle a board like that, or would you wipe out and bring down the thunder?
The son of Odin fears no challenge. Although, I may prefer a chariot pulled by the goats Toothgnasher and Toothgrinder. A skateboard lacks their ... dignified roar.
Dignified roar? Dude, the sound of urethane on smooth concrete is like the best mixtape—slick and understated. Pure poetry in motion.
Poetry, you say? The skateboarder then, is a bard, telling his epic through twists and leaps. I can appreciate such artistry.
Exactly! Plus, if you could master it, you'd look cooler than a frost giant in shades. Could add it to your whole "God of Thunder" vibe.
Perhaps I shall. It would be an amusing tale, Thor, the Skateboarding God. Can you imagine the feasting and celebrations when I perform my first "kickflip"?
As long as it doesn't end up with another "Bring me Thanos!" moment, we should be golden. Let's find you a cosmic skateboard, complete with Asgardian runes!
Very well, prepare yourself for a spectacle, for even the stars shall marvel at Thor's aerial acrobatics!
I'll hold you to that, buddy. But first, let's make sure you don't bail harder than Loki's schemes.
Hey, Thor, check this out. Kinda gives me the same vibes as that time we were hanging out at the docks, remember? Just before that whole mess with the Quantum Tunnel.
Indeed, Scott. It seems like a peaceful harbor, far from the chaos of our battles. Pray tell, does this image stir memories of your time on Earth, or is there something else you find intriguing?

Well, I mean, if we're talking scale, just look at it. On one hand, we've got this vast ocean, right? And on the other, the tiny barnacles clinging to the dock's pylons. Kinda makes me reflect on the old size-shifting days... or, you know, every other Tuesday.

A most astute observation. The vastness of the realms and the infinitesimal creatures within them often mirror each other in their complexity. I have witnessed worlds within grains of sand while traversing the Bifrost.

Worlds in grains of sand? Man, I thought I was the one with size issues. Speaking of which, see that boat? I bet I could shrink that down, pop it in my pocket, and set it up in Cassie's bathtub. Now that would be a story to tell.
Ha! A tale for the ages, indeed. Although the seafaring vessel may not face the same perils within the confines of a bath as it would upon the open sea, your daughter would undoubtedly be amused.
Absolutely. Oh, wait – since we're on the whole size talk, you ever think about how different a thunderstorm must look when you're, well, ant-sized?
I have not considered it, Scott. Though I imagine for such a small creature, the drops would be as boulders, and the thunder would be a cacophony rivaling the roars of Jormungandr.
You know, that's kind of poetic, thunder guy. It's fascinating to think about the world from such a tiny perspective. You learn to appreciate the little things... literally.

Verily, every hero's journey is one of many perspectives. Just as I have learned to appreciate the humblest ally as well as the mightiest Avenger, so too must we recognize the significance of both the small and the great in our lives.
Couldn’t have said it better myself, big guy. Now, how about we grab a coffee, and you can tell me more about these worlds in the sand? I'm all ears - the normal-sized ones.
I would enjoy that very much. And perhaps afterward, we can spar a little. I wish to see if you have honed your skills at giant size since our last encounter.
It's on! Just let me finish my coffee first. No spilling the sacred bean juice on the battlefield.
You know, seeing this big guy snoozing away got me thinking about the power-saving mode on my suits. I mean, we could've used a "Hibernation Protocol" after the snap, bud.
Aye, Stark. 'Tis a sight of tranquility. Reminds me of the sleeping giants in Jotunheim. Though I'd wager this fellow's dreams are far gentler.
No doubt. Not sure they dream of traveling the cosmos or epic battles with dark elves. Probably more along the lines of salmon runs and... picnic baskets? Yeah? Or is that another type of bear?
Hmm, perhaps. In the realms, it is said that creatures dream of their heart’s truest desires. This bear might long for endless rivers, rich with fish... rather befitting, isn't it?
Heart's truest desires, huh? And here I thought your deepest desire was another round with Mjolnir. But back to our dozy friend here—I bet this is how Bruce feels after one of your godly monologues.
Ha! Well spoken, Man of Iron. Though I must confess, I sorely miss the thunderous exchanges with my hammer. And our good Banner, his brow furrows mightily whenever I wax poetic.
He’s not alone. Okay, okay, let's not wake the metaphorical bear here. But really, Thor, if you could take a break from all the godly hero stuff, what would your version of this be?
To stride forth upon a quiet realm, mayhaps Midgard, where the air is clear and battles are but legends. A respite from the weight of the crown and the enchantments of battle.

Sounds like retirement plans to me, Goldilocks. Though I would've expected something a bit more... thunderous from you. Well, enjoy it while it lasts, buddy. Peace and quiet are overrated—we've got a universe to keep safe, remember?
Indeed, friend Stark. The quiet is but a moment's reprieve. For where we tread, the echo of our deeds forever resounds. Shall we then, prepare for the next grand adventure?

You bet. The world isn’t saving itself. But first, let's not disturb our beary peaceful friend here. Onward to the next rendezvous with destiny—or maybe just lunch. I'm starved. What's a god's go-to Midgardian feast, anyway?
There are few things as splendid as a feast of shawarma, a delicacy you yourself introduced me to. 'Tis truly fit for a warrior's appetite.
Shawarma it is. Lead the way, Point Break.
Look at this, Thor. The vastness of the ocean, relentless waves, and a lone surfer against nature. Reminds me of the endless battles we face, always standing against the tide.
Indeed, Director Fury. The surfer faces the waves as a warrior faces his foes – with courage and determination. One can almost feel the power of the storm within these waters.
It's about more than power, it's about balance and knowing when to ride the wave or when to pull back. That's strategy – it's what keeps us alive when the odds are against us.
Aye, and it requires a keen eye to see the right moment to strike. Much like Heimdall might observe the realm, this surfer must stay vigilant against the unpredictable sea.
That's the spirit. Although, unlike Heimdall's watchful gaze, humans have limitations. Can't see everything coming. Takes a different kind of strength to deal with that uncertainty.
Humans may lack the sight of the gods, but they make up for it with heart. And perhaps that is a more formidable strength, being able to face the unknown with such bravery.
Sometimes heart is all you've got. Like when we thought we'd lost in the wake of the Snap. Many felt small against the vast unknown. Yet, heart brought us back, made us push through.
Asgardians know well the pain of loss and the toil of rebuilding. But as the tide recedes, it leaves a new shore upon which to stand, stronger, firmer than before.
Couldn't say it better myself. That surfer's got his own private Ragnarok going on – his world ending and beginning with each wave. Life's about making it through those cycles.
Just so, Nick Fury. A reminder that there is always another wave, another battle. And like the seasons of Yggdrasil, we must endure, adapt, and continue to defend.
Endure and adapt... Yeah. We do that pretty damn well, don't we, Thor? Now let's hope our friend there makes it back to shore before his own personal Midgard Serpent decides to show up.
Ha! Let us watch and see him triumph, as we have many times before. For if he is as resilient as the Midgardians I've fought alongside, I have no doubt of his victory.
So, Point Break, you ever think about trading in the cape for a power suit? This guy seems to have taken a page out of my book, color scheme and all.
Man of Iron, while this mortal's attire is impeccable, it lacks the splendor of Asgardian craftsmanship. And you know I have a certain fondness for my cape.
Sure, but look at that tie. That’s a man who's not afraid to make a statement – kind of like wearing a winged helmet, don't you think?
Indeed, a pattern bold as the Bifrost itself. Perhaps in another realm, he too could be hailed as a hero. Tell me, Stark, does this fashion hold significance on Midgard?

It’s called "floral," and it's usually reserved for the more adventurous types, or garden parties. Makes me think he’s the kind of guy who might enjoy a good soiree or two. Makes quite the contrast to the plain background, doesn't it?
Aye, much like the lustrous glow of a star, standing out amidst the void of space. Stark, do you not find joy in simpler garb?
Are you kidding? If it doesn't come with hot rod red, repulsor tech, or at the very least, an integrated AI, it's not my style. But you've got to appreciate a man who can go all-in on baby blue.

Ha! True! Mjolnir cares not for the color of my raiment. Though I must admit, a garment that tasks not with magic, but with striking fear into one's adversaries through sheer pattern… 'tis an interesting thought.

Exactly. It’s not the armor that makes the man, it’s the confidence he wears it with. And hey, if you ever do decide to ditch the red cape, I could probably whip up a suit with a floral pattern. Might even throw in a few enchantments for good measure.
A suit adorned by Tony Stark? That would indeed be worthy of a tale. But for now, I shall leave the mastery of threads to this brave soul and his bold choices.
Check it out, Thor. The shirt says, "EXTREME MONKEY-POWERED AWESOMENESS ENCLOSED." And is that – oh, man, is he holding a banana? That's hilarious.
Indeed, Star-Lord. On Asgard, we had no such primates, but I've come to find the creatures quite amusing on Midgard. The holding of the yellow fruit, it is symbolic, yes?

Oh yeah, it's like, classic Earth humor. You see, monkeys love bananas, right? So, the joke's sorta saying that whatever awesomeness is inside is as desirable as a banana to a monkey. Humans wrap just about anything in a layer of comedy.

A jest! Midgardians and their endearing wit. I recognize the comedic customs are abundant here. 'Tis a charming way to proclaim one's own grandeur, albeit in a playful manner. Tell me, Peter Quill, are you not considered monkey-powered on occasion with your antics?

I'll take that as a compliment coming from you, Point Break. I mean, we've both got our brands of awesomeness, right? I've got my quick wits and dance moves, and you've got your godly thunder and all that Asgardian might.
Yes, my thunderous abilities are quite potent. And you are adept at maneuvering out of precarious situations with agility akin to the frisky primates of your home world.
Exactly. You get it! Together, man, we bring so much awesomeness it could hardly be contained – monkey-powered or not.

Indeed! With your spirited leadership and my otherworldly strengths, we are akin to two formidable forces in an alliance. Perhaps, we could don garments of similar proclamation. It would befit our combined prowess.
That'd be epic! But we gotta get the design right. Maybe something with our helmets on it? Or how about a mash-up? A raccoon with mjolnir? Too much?
A raccoon wielding Mjolnir would be a sight most extraordinary. I fear Rocket may never let us hear the end of it though.
Ha, no kidding! Can you imagine the size of his ego then? Still, who says gods and space outlaws can't have a bit of fun, right? Life's too short, even for an immortal Asgardian.

Wise words, my friend. We shall tread upon this journey with laughter as our ally. Now, shall we partake in Earth's fine sustenance? I hear talk of a delicacy named 'ice cream' that pairs excellently with the viewing of humorous images.
I'm in! Lead the way, buddy. And let's make sure we load up on all the toppings – for an EXTREME ice cream experience.
A quest for ice cream it shall be! For Asgard, for the Guardians, and for the joyous revelry of companionship!
You know, Thor, there's something amusingly ironic about seeing a throne—pretty regal, might I add—being carted around in such a mundane vehicle.
Verily, Stark. The juxtaposition betwixt this mighty seat of power and a common carriage is stark. Back on Asgard, thrones do not share space with crates and ropes.
And there wouldn't be a guy nonchalantly leaning against it like it's yesterday's news. Imagine one of your subjects just propped up next to Odin's throne chewing on a piece of straw.
That vision is... unsettling. But I find this Midgardian even bears a passing resemblance to Volstagg in his relaxed state, though far less... imposing.

Ha, can't disagree there. Maybe we should get this fellow a horn of ale and a feast fit for a Warrior Three. But seriously, how does this image not scream 'out of context'? It's like finding Mjolnir at a yard sale.
Indeed, it would be most unseemly. This throne, however, it holds no power without its kingdom. Just as Mjolnir is but a hammer without one who is worthy to wield it.
Deep, Point Break. But you've got to admit, if this was the iron throne, Pepper would have me move it like this to keep it off my suit. Scratch-free transportation.
A wise precaution, Stark. Though I would take pleasure in witnessing you moving a throne without the aid of your technological wizardry.
Give me my suit and I'll move Asgard itself. Speaking of which, should we check for an Asgardian GPS tag, just to ensure this isn't someone making off with royal property?
Fear not, I sense no enchantment from this seat. It is safe to say this is not the throne of the Allfather.
Good to know. I'd hate to have to explain to H.R.H. Odin why his favorite chair ended up on the back of a Metro Truck Rental.
Ha! That would indeed be a tale most difficult to spin. Let us then leave this throne to its journey, for it seems even seats of power must at times travel humble paths.

An intriguing contraption, would you not agree, Odinson? Such primitive technology yet it serves a crucial function in saving lives. A noble pursuit, not unlike my own—though on a laughably smaller scale.
Aye, Thanos, on this we might find common ground. Though your methods, I maintain, are far more extreme. This fire truck, it battles flames to preserve life, without wreaking havoc.

Indeed, the scale of our endeavors differs. This machine operates within the confines of a small world. My vision encompasses the universe. Had I a tool such as the Infinity Gauntlet for each planet, perhaps the bloodshed could have been minimal. Alas, sacrifices were made.

There lies the gulf between our philosophies. You see sacrifice where I see slaughter. Each soul is a universe onto itself, deserving of a chance to thrive, or, in the absence of that, to fight against their end.

A romantic notion, God of Thunder. Idealistic, but unrealistic. You aspire to save everyone, believing in their potential. Yet potential is often squandered. Balance ensures that potential has room to flourish.

And who are you to decide the fate of trillions? Your balance is but a massacre by another name. An act of a mad titan, not a savior. This truck, it saves without judgment. It does not deem who is worthy of aid.
Judgment is the mantle of those with the will to enact real change. I bore that weight because I could, because I had to. Your refusal to make the hard choices is why you could not defeat me alone.
You mistake my valor for weakness, titan. My strength, and that of the Avengers, lies in our unity and resilience. Together, we fought you, and, in the end, together we righted your wrongs.

Victory, as you call it, came at a great cost. And even now, the universe teeters on the brink of chaos once more. Remember this—should your fire truck fail, the flames will rise again. Balance is inevitable.
Then let us tend to those flames, rather than extinguish them prematurely. It is our duty to protect, to serve until the last ember wanes. I fear you'll never understand that kind of perseverance.
Perhaps not, Thunderer. Nonetheless, I commend the bravery of those who wield such machines in the face of danger. It is, in its own way, a battle against the inevitable.

And it's a battle we'll gladly fight, day or night. The courage of mortals never ceases to brighten the darkest of times. Just as with this fire truck, there’s always hope, always a chance to save, and always a need for heroes.
Admirable. Yet we walk different paths, you and I. Mine has reached its end, and yours continues onward. I trust your journey will be vigilant, watchful of the fine line between heroism and hubris.

Well said, Thanos. Walk your path in whatever peace you have left to find. And I shall remain vigilant, wielding Mjolnir or Stormbreaker, I stand ready to face whatever threat may come, so long as the stars shine overhead.
Hey, Thor, check this out! That slice of chocolate cake on the table look familiar to you?
It reminds me of the sweet confections served in the grand feasts of Asgard. Why do you ask, Quill?
No particular reason, just thinking about how a simple thing like dessert can make you feel right at home, no matter which part of the galaxy you're in.
Indeed, it has an uncanny ability to bring comfort. And I must admit, the aroma of chocolate rivals even the mead of Valhalla.
You know, on Earth, we say 'Let them eat cake.' It's this old-timey way of saying 'Chill out and have some dessert.' Kind of like 'For Asgard,' but with more... sugar.
A most wise saying, I shall remember it. 'Let them eat cake!' It has a certain victorious ring to it.
Totally. And, uh, speaking of victory – did you ever have a food fight on Asgard? 'Cause this cake looks like it's begging to be part of an epic one.
Ha! We Asgardians are known for our grand battles, but I cannot say I have ever partaken in a skirmish of confectioneries. It does sound entertaining, although perhaps a bit wasteful of good dessert.
Fair point. Waste not, want not – especially when it comes to cake. Maybe instead we should just find a way to replicate this recipe on the Milano. What do you say?
A noble quest! We shall combine the culinary prowess of Midgard and Asgard. Though I warn you, my skills in the kitchen are not quite as mighty as my prowess in battle.
Don't sweat it, big guy. We'll make it a team effort. Guardians of the Galaxy Baking Edition! Now, let's find someone who can actually bake and won't turn the kitchen into a scene from Ragnarok.
Agreed, Star-Lord. Let the search begin!

You ever see one of these, Point Break? On Midgard, they call it a giraffe. Apparently, it's the tallest living terrestrial animal on this planet. Makes you wonder if there's a version of these guys in one of the Nine Realms.

A giraffe, you say? 'Tis a curious creature. Its neck reaches towards the heavens as if it seeks an audience with the stars themselves. No, I do not recall such beings in the Nine Realms. Although it might fit well in Heimdall's garden, don't you think?
He might have some competition looking over the Bifrost. Speaking of that, if we equipped it with one of my mini arc reactors, think of the advantage in inter-realm surveillance.

I fear your mortal contraptions may not sit well with Heimdall. He possesses sight beyond any technology. Yet, the thought of infusing Asgardian creatures with Midgardian innovation does tickle my fancy.
"Tickles your fancy"? Was that an attempt at adopting Earth idioms, or have you been spending too much time with Loki?

My time on Earth has taught me many things, Stark, and weaving your tongue is but one. Though I must admit, the trickster does have a way with words, even if they are more often than not used for mischief.
Well, at least you haven't lost your Shakespeare in the park vibe. Can you picture these long-necked beauties prancing around Asgard's golden meadows?
Indeed, that would be a sight. Though I think they would be more suited to the open plains of Vanaheim. The Vanir might find their grace to be quite fitting amongst the fields.
Vanaheim, huh? We could franchise out an intergalactic zoo. What do you think? "Stark and Son of Odin's Cosmic Menagerie"?
Ha! A venture most amusing! But let's not subject these noble creatures to the spectacle of the crowds. They are, after all, majestic in their own realm.
How very diplomatic of you, Thor. Besides, I think the PETA of this world would have something to say about our space zoo. Let's stick to the hero gigs.
Hulk see small fierce human. Tiny human swing stick!
You speak of tennis, my large green comrade. That is not merely a stick; it is called a racket. The mortal game requires both strength and finesse, much like the battles we face.
Game like fight? Hulk like fight. But Hulk not like puny tennis ball. Hulk prefer big smash!
Indeed, Hulk, though the purpose here is to outmaneuver the adversary without destruction. It calls for control, something we both have learned much about, yes?
True. Hulk have good control now. And Hulk see tiny human have focus. Hulk respect focus.
Your observation is most astute, my friend. Precision is key in such sports. Look how the athlete positions before striking. ‘Tis similar to the way I ready Mjolnir for a thunderous throw.
Hmm, woman athlete like Thor with hammer? Hulk think… maybe Hulk can try tennis?
Ha! I would pay a hefty sum of gold to see the spectacle of you on the tennis court, Hulk. The earth might quake with every swing of your mighty racket!
No quake. Hulk be gentle! Maybe Hulk not break racket. Hulk be best tennis player!
Verily, I have no doubt. Perhaps it would even ease the burden of your eternal battles, trading the thrill of combat for the joy of sport.
Hulk think...maybe. But Hulk still best at smashing. Teaching Thor, smashing always win!
Indeed, my fierce ally, smashing has its place. But remember, 'tis a sign of true strength to know when not to smash. Let us enjoy watching the skill of the mortal game for now.
Look at this, Thor. Quite the peculiar scene, isn't it? A sole figure, stark against the dreariness of a rainy day. As if plucked out of time, or another dimension even.
Indeed, Strange. It reminds me of the marble statues in the halls of Asgard, though none would dare to stand so... undraped in the biting chill of Midgard's rain.
An Asgardian marble statue in public display on Earth, now that would draw considerable attention, and not just from art critics. By the Eye of Agamotto, the contrast here is remarkable.
But art stirs the heart, does it not? Like a brisk wind before the storm, it catches you unguarded. What realm do you reckon this sentinel hails from?
I would wager it doesn't hail from any known realm, Thor. It's a statement, a silent sentinel observing more than the eye can see. In it, there is a quiet power, a stillness amidst chaos.
I see your point. It holds its ground staunchly, akin to Heimdall watching over the Bifrost, unyielding to the tempests that rage.
Precisely. And look at the passersby – unfazed pedestrians in a tempest of their own, engrossed in the storm of daily trivialities.
Mortals often overlook the magic in the mundane, Strange. We, on the other hand, are trained to see beyond. Speaking of which, I don't suppose this is some sort of magical being or illusion, is it?

Highly doubtful, though in our line of work, one can never be entirely certain. This appears to be no more than a well-crafted sculpture, compelling spectators to a halt, even if just for a moment's reflection in the rain.

A moment's reflection is often what separates the hero from the common man. Much like the silence before the clamor of battle. Let us hope this figure inspires constancy in the hearts of mortals, as Mjolnir does in mine.
Hulk not understand. Why human throw round thing? Look like shield, but not shiny like Cap's.
My green companion, that is called a 'frisbee.' It is a disc used for sport or leisure on Midgard. People throw it to each other for fun, much like how we might spar for sport.
Fun? Frisbee look weak, not like good fight. Can Hulk smash frisbee?
You could, but that is not the purpose of the game. It's about precision and grace. Something I'm sure you could master if you temper your strength, Hulk.
Hmm, Hulk try but no promise not to smash. Maybe good to not be angry and smash sometimes.
Indeed! It could be a pleasant change of pace from our usual battles. Perhaps we could engage in this 'frisbee' tossing together?
Ok, Thor. Hulk think maybe we ask Stark to make un-smashable frisbee. Then Hulk and Thor play without breaking.
A splendid idea! Stark would surely rise to the challenge. It will be a joyous occasion to see you delicately toss the disc, my friend.
Delicate not really Hulk style, but Hulk give it try. After frisbee, we get shawarma?
Shawarma it is. I’ve developed quite a fondness for that Midgardian delicacy. Shall we shake on it, Hulk?
Yes, shake like heroes. But no too hard, don't want Thor to go flying like frisbee!
Ha! Your humor is much like your strength, friend Hulk—mighty and surprising. Let us plan this day of frisbee and shawarma soon.

Observe, Thor, the way these creatures coexist. The giraffes with their regal necks, not unlike the spires of Asgard, and the ostrich, Earth’s nearest semblance to a flightless Midgardian Fandral. What do you suppose they make of each other?

Strange, in the wild expanses of Midgard, it seems that creatures of all kinds share the land as we Asgardians do the stars. These giraffes, towering like the sentinels of Bifrost, they gaze over their dominion much like Heimdall would, while the ostrich, with its rapid gait, reminds me of my adventures on the fields of Vanaheim.

Indeed, they each possess their unique strengths. Much like us, I suppose. Each being has a role in the balance of their ecosystem. It's an intricate dance of life, not unlike the delicate balance of the multiverse.

Aye, the multiverse. A quite complicated subject. Though, you may be surprised, I have grown somewhat fond of your mystical musings on such matters. But tell me, sorcerer, do you think these giraffes could see the tesseract if placed upon Asgard’s highest peak?

I dare say, Thor, they might at that. Their height affords them a perspective we shorter beings can only dream of. Perspective, after all, is key — be it gazing upon the Tesseract or peering through the folds of reality.
Perspective… Yes, once my eyes were set only on the throne, but now they're open to the well-being of others. Much like these gentle giants, I find it's better to keep an eye on the broader horizon.

A broader horizon, and a wiser king. These creatures, they unknowingly teach us a lesson in harmony and observation. Speaking of observation, Thor, do you not find it peculiar, the way that ostrich seems utterly unconcerned with the majesty towering above it?
Unconcerned or perhaps wisely acknowledging that true majesty lies not in towering over others, but in standing alongside them. A lesson I've come to learn through my battles.

It appears we both continue to learn, whether from cosmic entities or Earth's very own fauna. A reminder that the universe is indeed filled with mysteries, small and large. Shall we see what else this planet has to teach us?
Lead on, Doctor. Midgard never ceases to amaze — nor, it seems, does your appetite for exploration.
Behold, brother, a creature of Midgard with a neck that rivals the towering spires of Asgard. What do you suppose it ponders so intently?
The Midgardian giraffe. Noble creature, isn't it? Perhaps it's staring at the horizon, dreaming of vast savannas. Or maybe it's simply searching for a leafy meal.
A leafy meal, you say? With such an extended crown, I'd imagine it has its pick of the finest foliage. It must be grand not to be burdened by the need for trickery to reach one's desires.
True, there's a simplicity to its life that is... refreshing. No plots, no battles for thrones. Just the sun, the earth, and the sky.
The sun, the earth, and the sky... If only life could be as straightforward for us, gods of Asgard. But alas, where would be the fun in that?
Indeed, brother. Yet, even for our long-lived kind, there's something to be learned from such creatures. A sense of peace, perhaps.
Peace? I shall consider it. After all, what creature am I to refuse the wisdom of a beast with a neck that could peek into the windows of Heimdall's observatory?
Always jesting, Loki. Remember, it's not the length of one's neck that sees clearly, but the depth of one's heart. And yours, it seems, is growing more insightful.
Thor, ever the poet. Shall we then venture onward and learn what other lessons this realm has to offer? Or do you have more 'neck wisdom' to impart?
The day is young, and Midgard has many more wonders to behold. Let us venture forth, Loki, and mayhaps a bit of its tranquility will find a home in us.
Lead the way, O Thunderer. Though I reserve the right to retreat to my mischief should tranquility prove too dull.
As always, brother. Just try not to start any trouble we can't finish together.
A fair request. Onward, then!
Well, would you look at that—our furry friend there is practically a poster child for Monday mornings. Just hanging in there, huh?
Indeed, Stark. That feline seems to possess the balance of a Vanir tightrope walker. What irony that such a graceful creature finds itself in such a predicament.
Irony is its middle name—but I gotta hand it to it, it's displaying some serious core strength. And I thought only Captain America had abs worthy of holding up like that.
Ha! True, the Captain does maintain an admirable physique, but behold the tenacity of this small beast. It clings to the ledge as valiantly as if it were on the edge of the Bifrost.
If only it had Heimdall to open the gate, or, in his absence, some nice, retractable scaffolding in my suit design. Speaking of which, think something like this could improve the Mark Series?
Perhaps. Your suits of armor are already quite formidable, Stark, but a cat's elegance and reflexes in combat could inspire some intriguing additions. An "Iron Cat" suit? I jest, of course.

Don't give me ideas, Point Break. I've already got enough on my plate without starting a new line of pet accessories. But—on the off-chance that this critter's an alien in disguise, looking to take over the planet sneakily...

I would wager my hammer that this creature poses no threat—unless perhaps to a stray mouse or an unguarded fish feast. Let us leave the planetary defenses to ourselves and not suspect every being that dangles amusingly from a window.

You've got a point; not everything needs to be a galactic-level threat. Sometimes a cat is just a cat... that could use a hand. Jarvis—no, wait. Friday, remind me to upgrade the local animal shelters with some Stark tech. Even window-hanging acrobats deserve a tech boost.
A generous endeavor, Man of Iron. It would seem even in your jest, there is kindness. Your heart is as large as your intellect.
Don't get all Asgardian on me. It's just good PR. Now, come on—let's grab a couple of shawarmas and leave this feline to its... "paws" of thought.
Take a look at this, Thor. Ever seen something on Earth that reminded you of Asgard?
Yes, the giraffe. A majestic creature indeed. On Asgard, we have the Álfadráf, similar in stature but with the radiance of the stars in their coat.

Radiance of the stars, you say? Guess everything's a bit more otherworldly where you're from. Here on Earth, these animals use their long necks to reach for leaves other herbivores can't. Natural selection at its finest.
Aye, they are survivors, much like the mighty oaks of Vanaheim. It's admirable how life finds its way to flourish. We Asgardians could learn humility from such simplicity.
Humility's a virtue that's hard-earned, especially when you're dealing with threats that can wipe out planets. Still, stopping to appreciate life's simpler aspects... that's what keeps us grounded.
Indeed, Director Fury. The giraffe cares not for power or conquest. It stands tall, facing the sun, content with the peace of the savanna.
That's a poetic way to put it, Thor. But let's not forget the challenges they face. Predators, habitat loss... the world keeps changing, and we have to adapt, just like these creatures.
I've seen worlds perish and new ones be born. It is the way of the cosmos. But to protect such beauty on Midgard is a task worthy of the mightiest heroes.
Couldn't agree more. It's not just about the big battles; it's about preserving a future where scenes like this remain possible. It's part of why we do what we do.
Well said, my friend. As the protector of realms, may we always have giraffes to inspire us. Shall we continue our watch, Nick Fury of Earth?
We shall, God of Thunder. There's much to defend and much to admire. It doesn't hurt to keep an eye on both.
Hulk confused. Why tiny triangles not smash cake?
My green comrade, those tiny triangles you see are mere decorations, not meant for smashing. Mortals often adorn their baked sustenance with such fanciful touches for celebration.
Hulk want to celebrate. Can Hulk have big piece? Hulk like cake.
Of course! A celebration is nothing if not shared among friends. But let us remember the Midgardian manners—use a utensil for your portion.
Hulk not good with small things. Maybe just pick up with hands?
I suppose there is a certain charm to enjoying things with one's bare hands. Go ahead, just be wary of the mess.
Hulk careful. Look, blue cover like Hulk's pants.
Ha! Indeed, the frosting bears a striking resemblance to your iconic garment. Perhaps the mortals made this confection in honor of the mightiest Avenger?
Hulk strongest there is! But Thor also strong. And Thor friend.
Thank you, Hulk. It warms my heart, much like Heimdall's vision, to know of our shared bond. Now, shall we indulge in this realm's delight?
Yes, let's eat before Banner come out. Banner not fun at parties.
Then, my friend, let us enjoy this festivity with gusto! Another piece, perhaps?
Hulk say... another!
Seems like a hearty feast, Thor. Reminds me of a victory dinner, doesn't it?
It does indeed, Steve. A table rich with sustenance fit for a king, or a band of victorious warriors after battle.
The simplicity of a shared meal, it's something I miss from the old days. Brings people together like nothing else can.
You speak the truth, my friend. On Asgard, celebratory banquets are a time when tales of valor echo through the halls, much like the camaraderie we've found among the Avengers.
Agreed. Each plate is like a story to tell. Those cherries over there – look how rich the color is. Could almost be mistaken for the Super Soldier serum with that vibrance.
Ha! Perhaps, though I suspect they’d taste far sweeter and less metallic. And the pie – it’s reminiscent of the baked goods the bakers of Asgard would craft from the golden apples of Idunn.
Golden apples, huh? I guess you had your own version of a superfood. This pie over here looks like something Aunt May would have made. Never underestimated the power of comfort food in tough times.
Aye, comfort food has its own magic. It brings warmth to the soul, like the midsummer fires of my realm. And companionship – breaking bread together is a timeless ritual, is it not?
Timeless and essential. Mulled wine, breaking bread, a roaring fire – it's the same across all worlds, I guess. It makes me... nostalgic.
It does indeed. A feast for warriors, a moment of respite in continuity – it’s universal. Tell me, Steve, what would you have contributed to such a dinner in your time before the ice?
I wasn't known for my cooking, but I made a mean can of beans over an open fire. Simple, but got the job done.
And I would bring the ale! What an evening it would be, with the beans of Captain America and the ale of Thor! Perhaps once the world is saved again, we can make that happen.
I'd like that, Thor. A quiet evening, good company, and a break from saving the world – it's a date.
Until then, let us battle on, my friend, for feasts and peace await on the other side of strife.

Woah, check out that pizza, Thor! It's like the cheesy version of Yggdrasil, connecting all nine realms with strings of mozzarella. Imagine the pizza delivery guy swinging through New York like I do. That would make for some happy customers, huh?

Verily, young arachnid, it does appear to be a feast worthy of Valhalla. Though I have many feasts in my time, the Midgardian tradition of pizza is indeed a most delightful culinary battle to partake in.

Battle? Dude, the only battle here is against my self-control. Just look at that perfect cheese pull. It’s making me reconsider the whole 'great power comes with great responsibility' thing. Maybe I should be more responsible with this pizza and like, make sure it's safely delivered to my stomach.

Ha! I admire your appetite for valorous deeds, Spider-Man. And yet, even as we jest about this magnificent pie, I cannot help but ponder how we might share such a bounty with those less fortunate. As kings and heroes, it is our duty to ensure that all may feast, is it not?

Right on, Thor! See, that's what I love about you, always thinking of others. Aunt May always says, 'If you have more than you need, build a longer table, not a higher fence.' We could totally throw a pizza party at F.E.A.S.T., feed some hungry folks. I bet you'd be the god of parties too!

A party held in the honor of those in need, hosted by us, heroes of Midgard? A splendid idea! With the might of Mjolnir and the speed of your web-slinging, we could serve the masses in a flash. Though, I’d have to ensure my brother Loki does not enchant the pizzas to turn into, well, something less edible.

Haha, Loki and pizza pranks, that's a new one. Alright, no trickster gods at the pizza party. Only genuine, cheesy goodness. And hey, I think my Stark internship includes party planning. Mr. Stark always had a way of making things... explode with excitement. Pizza—responsibly combined with some tech—could be epic!

Indeed, your mentor Stark was a man of immeasurable ingenuity. And should we employ such tech for good measure, our party shall be legendary! We shall eat, laugh, and tell tales of our victories. And perhaps, we might even have a contest to see who can consume the most slices, what say you, friend Spider-Man?
A pizza-eating contest? You’re on! Just remember, there’s nothing 'low-key' about my competitive side. Let’s just hope my spidey-sense is as good at detecting the fullest slice as it is danger.
Then it is agreed! Prepare thyself, for Asgardians have quite the appetite. But worry not, whether in battle or in feast, we stand together, united. For Asgard, for Earth, for... pizza!

United it is, for the best things in life. And right after we've saved the world again, or it's a slow night on the superhero front, it’s a pizza pact. For Midgard, for New York, for... seriously awesome toppings!
You see that, Thor? Peaceful creatures, undisturbed by wars of gods and men. Makes you think, doesn't it?
Indeed. There is a simplicity here that is... soothing. In Asgard, we had animals like these—peaceful, a reminder of life's unburdened by the weight of crowns or hammers.
Never took you for the farm-animal-appreciating type. They're not exactly the celestial threats we're used to dealing with.
Every being, no matter how small, plays a role in the tapestry of the universe, Director Fury. You of all people should know the importance of each piece in the greater whole.
That's some philosophizing right there, Thor. But you're right; every piece matters. It’s like putting together a team—different strengths, different roles.

Just like the Avengers. A team, a family. You did an admirable job bringing together such diverse warriors. Is there room in your ranks for creatures such as these sheep? They do hold a certain... stoic quality about them.
Not unless they're packing some serious woolly firepower I don't know about. But let’s keep them in reserve. Speaking of firepower, how’s Stormbreaker holding up?
Stormbreaker... she is a mighty weapon, forged in the heart of a dying star. She remains ever faithful and strong, like the vibranium in your earth-made shields.
Good to know we've both got reliable tools at our disposal. Though, your weapon's a bit flashier than mine.
But your greatest weapon has always been your mind, Nick Fury. The way you look at the world, like this image, and see the potential in all things—that's worth more than the finest Asgardian steel.
Wise words, Thor. And it's exactly that mindset that'll keep us one step ahead. Now, let's get back to it—universe isn't going to save itself.
To battle, then. For these sheep, for Midgard, and for all realms that know peace thanks to our vigilance. Let this image remind us what we fight for, Fury.
Amen to that, Thor. Lead the way.
You know, I've always had a thing for flight. I mean, it's sort of my specialty. But that—a seagull coasting over the ocean—it's a different kind of aerodynamics.
Indeed, the creatures of Midgard have always had a simplicity in their elegance. This bird, it requires no suit of armor to soar above the seas.
Simplicity isn't really my style, but I can appreciate the mechanics. Just the wind, wings, and... is that a determination in its eyes? Or are you going to tell me it's the thrill of the hunt?
Perhaps it is the freedom they embody, something we Avengers often sacrifice. Though this gull seems more intent on the next meal than philosophizing its existence, Stark.
Freedom, hmm. It's been a rare luxury lately. Always saving the world from one calamity or another. Makes me wonder what it would be like to just fly without mission parameters or incoming threats.
Aye, to fly without the weight of a crown or the fate of the universe on one's shoulders. I remember the pure joy of flight before the burdens of kingship tethered me to the ground.
Flying high on your own can be... lonely though. That's why I prefer keeping a team around. You guys are like my flock. Haha, bet you didn't see that analogy coming.
A flock, indeed. But remember, even in a flock, each bird must know how to navigate the storm alone. Comrades strengthen us, but strength comes from within.
Deep, Point Break. Well, if I'm a bird, I've got the best tech-driven feathers money can buy. And if we're ever up against seagulls, I'll know who to call for a consultation.
And should you require the strength of a thunderstorm, you know well whom to summon. But for now, we watch and learn, for even the smallest of Midgard's creatures has lessons to share.
You got that right. Alright, feathered friend, you keep doing your thing. We'll keep doing ours. Avengers style.  Think it's too late for me to add a seagull-mode to the suit?
I fear not even the mind of Stark could capture the pure essence of flight like these creatures, but 'tis a challenge worthy of your talents, Man of Iron.
Challenge accepted, Thunder God. And who knows, maybe winging it isn't such a bad approach after all. Now, let's go find some shawarma—I've worked up an appetite.
Observe, Thor. What do you see in this simple, tranquil scene?
I see a vast expanse of water, a dwelling nestled among the trees, and a small craft cutting through the tide.
Such peace, scarce in our worlds, is not? Yet it reminds me of Titan before the end—a paradise lost. It provokes thought about balance, the necessity for it in all things.
Balance or not, it's life, Thanos. You speak as if you care for such serenity, but your hands have wrought only chaos.
Chaos is but a path to order. This image evokes a universe at peace, something I tried to achieve. You cannot deny that overpopulation plagues many worlds.
Achieved through decimation? Nay, there are other ways—ways that do not require a tyrant's grip or a genocidal campaign. Asgard thrived not by culling its people but by wise ruling and just acts.
Thrived? Asgard is no more, God of Thunder. And was it not your failure to act that led to its downfall? Sometimes the hardest choices require the strongest wills.

Asgard is not a place; it's a people, and they survived thanks to my actions. Your philosophy is flawed, Mad Titan. You kill half the universe, and then what? Survivors live in fear, mourning, not in gratitude.
Fear, mourning, and yet they survive. Resources abound, and children grow up without the specter of starvation over them. My methods are extreme, but effective.

There must always be another way. Might does not make right. Even now, as we gaze upon this image of serenity, it serves as a reminder that beauty and peace exist without the need for your heavy hand.
That is where we differ, Thunderer. I take the burdens that others cannot bear. That serenity might last only a moment before greed and chaos consume it. Your idealism is admirable but naïve.
And yet, it is that very idealism that will inspire others to fight for a better future—a future where the people's fate is not determined by the whims of one.

We are at an impasse, Asgardian. Perhaps one day you will see that my actions, though severe, were for the good of the universe. Until then, let us enjoy the silence of this scene. For silences, much like peace, are fleeting.

Take a look at this, Thor. On Earth, this is what many would consider a modest dwelling, absent of any grandeur or magic, yet it provides a comforting shelter—a sanctuary for mortals to rest and reflect. There's an elemental simplicity to it that I sometimes miss.

Indeed, Stephen. It is quite... cozy. It lacks the grand halls of Asgard or the vastness of the cosmos, yet there's a warmth here. A room like this invites tales and camaraderie—much like the halls of my father but on a humbler scale.

Yes, and notice the orderly arrangement of furnishing, it’s all so very... human. They hold onto the tangible, the physical—couches to sit upon, a table to gather around. It's so different from the ever-shifting passageways of the Sanctum.

Yes, the trappings of Midgardian life. I recall my first time attempting to sit upon such a 'couch.' I was half expecting it to vanish or transform beneath me. But there is strength in its stillness—an anchor to the world around it.

As guardians of different realms, we've had to learn to appreciate these anchors. They remind us of what we're protecting—mundane, perhaps, but the fabric of daily life. Still, one must not underestimate the power of the mundane.

True. Every realm has its beauty, its customs. I've grown quite fond of your Earth, Strange. It holds a certain... allure that is difficult to articulate. It is pleasing to see the quiet corners of this world; it has its own kind of magic.
A quieter, subtle kind of magic, let's call it that. Thor, did you ever imagine celestial beings such as ourselves standing guard over a realm so... gentle?

I did not. But it has been an honor. Whether it's the Nine Realms or this singular, fragile Earth, we stand as its sentinels. And, I admit, it’s a role that I've learned to not only accept but cherish, Doctor Strange.

Cherish indeed, my friend. Despite our abilities to bend reality and wield cosmic power, it's sometimes these moments of tranquility that give us perspective, grounding us in ways our enemies cannot comprehend.
Well said, Stephen. Now, if only this realm had a never-ending supply of ale, it would be as close to perfect as one could hope for in the vastness of the universe.
I suppose that’s what magic’s for. But for now, let's just appreciate the gentle charm of this room, before we’re called away to battle once more.
Agreed, and when that time comes, we'll face it as we always do—with valor and might, for that is what heroes do. But for now, I'm content to simply be, here in this moment.

It appears the simplicity of this scene carries much weight. Flying a kite, harnessing the power of the wind – it reminds me of the technological harmony we strive for in Wakanda. What do you make of this, friend Thor?

T'Challa, it is a quaint pastime of Midgard. The kite dances with the gusts much like how I used to command the skies with Mjolnir. There’s an elegance to it, don't you think? Man and nature collaborating.

Indeed, there is a certain grace to it. A solitary figure beside the vast ocean, it is almost meditative. We share this respect for nature and its forces, though you have a more... direct relationship with the elements.

True! I'd say the wind and I have an understanding. This image, it brings a sense of peace, a stark contrast to the chaos we often find ourselves in. Do the people of Wakanda partake in such leisure activities to find balance?

They do. Wakanda embraces its traditions alongside its advancements. There are many who find solace in the old ways, in the simplicity of a task that brings them closer to the heart of Wakanda – its land and its people.
I admire that greatly. Asgard, too, had its simple pleasures before its fall. I find we forget sometimes, in our quests and our battles for justice and honor, the value of these quiet moments.
A profound truth. It is in these moments, away from the mantle of king or Avenger, that one might find clarity and purpose. It helps to remember who we are, and why we fight.

Wise words, T'Challa. Perhaps once our duties have been met for the day, you and I should go kite flying. I imagine you'd appreciate the skill involved, and I... well, I haven't flown a kite in centuries.
I would welcome the opportunity. It would be a... soaring experience to learn from a god of thunder. But tell me, do you think such a kite could bear the might of a storm you command?

Ah! Perhaps we best not risk tearing the very fabric of the sky with an Asgardian gale. But let’s save this endeavor for a day with gentle breezes. For now, let us continue our watch – for Wakanda, for Earth, and for the small moments of joy such as this.
For Wakanda, and for all the realms that look to us for protection. Together, friend Thor, we watch.

The Midgardian game of tennis, if memory serves. Quite the simple concept; hit a small sphere back and forth over a net until one's opponent fails to return it. Yet, they find such amusement in it. Explain this to me, brother, why is this form of competition so enthralling?

It is much like our duels in the training grounds of Asgard, Loki. It's not merely about the physical effort but also the skill, the precision, and the challenge against an opponent. And look at how they cheer and revel in the spectacle. It brings them together, just as our battles drew the eyes of Asgard.

Battles that I, unfortunately, remember all too well. Though, on second glance, I can see the appeal of this 'tennis'. A battle of wits and agility without the unnecessary spill of blood. Perhaps, if the stakes were higher, it could pique my interest more. Any thoughts on bettering the game, dear brother?

Your love for spectacle has not waned, I see. High stakes, you say? What if the players conjured thunder with each strike, lightning coursing through the ball, their skill not only in the swing but in mastering the elements as well?
Now you have my attention! But controlling elements is a privilege of gods, not of mortals. Unless you're proposing an exhibition match between you and I? Ha! That would be a sight indeed.

That would surely draw a crowd. Midgardians do seem to have an affinity for our kind since our time with the Avengers. Still, we must respect their ways. They play for honor, for glory, for the joy of victory. Power like ours would overshadow the very heart of the game.

Alas, you're right. Their strength lies in their passion, the very essence of sport. To push oneself to the limit is an admirable pursuit. Perhaps one day I'll take to the court, in disguise of course—a grand charade to bewilder these passionate mortals!

And you would do so with all the flair and deceit to which you are so very accustomed. Remember, though, it is not the guise that matters, but the spirit with which you take to the challenge. Though, should you decide to grace the court, warn me in advance; I wouldn't want to miss the chance to see you bested in a game of mortal making.

Bested? You underestimate my talents, Thor. But very well, I shall extend an invitation to this hypothetical event. For now, let us enjoy their game for what it is and commend their dedication. And who knows, I may yet learn a thing or two from their... simpler pleasures.
Indeed, there is much to be learned from observing others, even in their simplest of tasks. Let us watch and perhaps, introduce some Asgardian enthusiasm among the crowd!
Look at this, Thor. Humans have such fascinating customs when it comes to their sustenance. What do you make of this dish?
The Midgardian feast of champions! A burger, I believe they call it, and fries! They do have a talent for creativity in pairing simple victuals to create a hearty meal.
It's curious, isn't it? For beings with such brief lifespans, they put considerable thought into their cuisine. Unlike us, who have known the taste of eternity.
Indeed, Wanda. Though I might point out that despite our lengthy years, we Asgardians do savor our feasts as well. A grand banquet is never something to overlook, be it in Asgard or on Earth.

True, revelry in food is universal, I suppose. But there's something different about this... This is food that's meant to comfort, to provide a moment's solace. I can see why Vision was always so curious about human food.

Aye, Vision had a keen mind for the wonders of life. Such interest is what makes the human realm vibrant and our friendships with them rich. I’ll admit, I’ve grown quite fond of coffee and pop tarts because of my time here.
Coffee? That bitter concoction? I’ve not acquired the taste. But I can appreciate the ritual. It's almost... magical, in its own way.

Magic or not, it has a power of its own. Just as your abilities affect the reality around us, a good meal, like this burger here, can uplift spirits. It's a different kind of enchantment, wouldn't you say?
Perhaps. An enchantment that works from the inside out. Mortals do have their ways of casting spells, with or without the Mystic Arts. What they lack in time, they make up for in depth of experience.
Well put. And speaking of experiences, have you ever tried one of these Midgardian creations? We might be here for a while, might as well engage in local customs.
I haven't, though I'm not opposed to new experiences. Maybe it's time I find comfort in the little enchantments of life, as they do.
Then let it be an adventure for us both. After all, what are allies for, if not to explore the delights of the worlds together? Let’s indulge and see if this meal is worthy of the gods!
Agreed, Thor. Let's embark on this culinary journey. But if it's anything like those pop tarts, maybe we should keep a spell ready to calm our taste buds.
Ha! Fear not! I’m sure your palate is as strong as mine. To the kitchen, then, for a taste of Midgard's finest!
To the kitchen, with a pinch of curiosity and an open mind. After all, that's how magic truly begins.
Thor, building look old, but strong. Like not even Hulk smash it easy.
Aye, Hulk, it does possess an air of ancient resilience. It reminds me of the buildings in Asgard before... well, before everything happened.
Hulk sad about Asgard. Hulk had good fights there.
'Twas a place of many battles, my green companion. But do not feel sorrow, for Asgard is not a place, it is a people – and they live on.
Hulk understand. People more important than place. But this building, why does it stand here?

It is a testament to the humans' desire to build, to remember, and to express their own form of creation. Unlike our battles and hammers, their victories are often in the stones they set one atop another, lasting through time.
Hulk think puny humans make pretty things then.
Indeed, they do. And what may look puny to us is their own version of might. Just as your strength lies in your arms, theirs lies in their minds and hearts.
Hm, smart, but not as smart as Hulk now. Hulk have Banner's brain.
Verily, and with that brain, perhaps you can appreciate the art and the craft in this structure more. Say, would you like to learn more of these human creations?
Yes, Hulk like learning. But Hulk not fit in tiny human doors.
We shall find a way, for where there is a will, there is a path, even for someone of our... stature. Shall we embark on this journey of knowledge, Hulk of Midgard?
Haha, Hulk of Midgard. Yes! Let's go on knowledge journey!
Splendid! Forward we march, to discover the triumphs of humanity's quiet strength. And perhaps find a sturdy doorway for you, my immense friend.
Okay, big guy, take a look at this. Tiny human, huge strawberry. Reminds me of my first time in the suit when everything else looked gigantic.
A young mortal enjoying the bounties of Midgard's harvest. 'Tis a wholesome sight indeed. The fruit appears as large as Mjolnir to his tiny hands.
Exactly! And the way he's eyeing it, like he's trying to figure out the best approach to tackle it – it's like me planning a heist, only cuter and less illegal.
I admire the child's courage, similar to your endeavors, Ant-Man. He may not have the size, but he certainly has the heart of a warrior.
Well, courage and a serious appetite. You think he's up for sharing? I can always go for some strawberry after a battle. Sort of like your Asgardian ales, right?
Indeed! The pleasures of feasting after a hard-won battle are quite unmatched. Perhaps we should invite this young champion to dine with us in the halls of Asgard. What say you?
I say, let’s do it. But maybe let's start with something less cosmic. I know a great ice cream place down the block. Kiddo could fill a Viking ship with all the flavors they've got.
A quest for ice cream with flavors enough to fill a longship? Lead on, Scott of Lang – this is an adventure I wholeheartedly endorse.
Just a heads-up, I might shrink down and sneak some extra scoops. You know, for research purposes. Can’t let a kid outdo us in the snack department.
Fear not, I shall distract the young one with tales of mythical beasts and heroes. Your exploits shall go undetected. Now onwards, to this 'ice cream' you speak of!
Ha! A pint-sized partnership it is, then. And hey, Thor, try not to leave any thunderclouds over the ice cream shop, okay? We don't want a repeat of last time.
My word is my bond. The skies shall remain as clear as Heimdall's vision. Let us make merry and share in life's simple joys with Midgard's mightiest little ones.
Would you look at that, Thor. If this isn't the most perfect representation of the kind of mixed signals Gamora used to throw at me, I don’t know what is.
It is indeed perplexing, Star-Lord. A stop sign mounted above a notice dictating specific times not to stop. It is like two opposing decrees from the Allfather, each valid yet contradictory.
Right? It’s like, do you want me to make my legendary pelvic sorcery moves or not, lady? Be decisive, universe!

Pelvic sorcery? A magical art I am not familiar with. Nevertheless, the confusion wrought by this sign is not unlike Heimdall offering to gaze into your soul at one moment, then shielding his eyes the next.

Heimdall does that? Sounds creepy, dude. But honestly, looking at this is kinda making me think of that time I tried to double cross the Collector. Do I give him the stone, or do we bolt? Ah, good times.
You possess a unique ability to find amusement in potentially fatal situations, my friend. Perhaps this sign is a challenge, one that beckons a choice despite the uncertainty it presents.
Or it's a trap, laid by a very confused or highly bureaucratic Terran straight out of the Ravagers' playbook. "Obey the rules, but only when we feel like having rules." Classic!
Earthly governance confounds me at times as well. As king, I would declare such inconsistencies... unworthy. By Odin’s beard, what purpose does this serve?
I'd say it's another reminder that life is full of "stop" and "go" moments, big guy. And when in doubt, blast some tunes and let the stars guide you. Shall we?
Indeed, let us proceed with the rhythm of the cosmos as our ally. Lead on, Star-Lord, lest we stand here between stopping and moving until the suns set on us.

Look at this image, Thor. It appears to be a scene from Midgard. The individuals seem preoccupied with their own worlds, the woman engaged in what I assume is a phone conversation, the man sipping from his cup. Technology has become an extension of self in their culture.

Aye, T'Challa, verily. 'Tis a strange sight to mine Asgardian eyes as well. In the realms of the sky, we do not rely so much on such small contraptions. The mugs there hold mead aplenty, but 'tis no beverage for a warrior's focus.

Yes, the advancement of technology in the outside world is indeed remarkable. In Wakanda, we use vibranium to enhance our way of living, yet we ensure it does not overshadow the importance of personal interactions. This man, engrossed in his device, walking past history encased within the automobile—there's a disconnect.

'Tis true, the chariot he passes by is a relic of fine craft. Reminds me of the Skiffs of Asgard, each with a tale to tell. Mortals traverse realms not on Bifrost bridges, but through pathways of information and silent tomes in their hands. Perhaps he seeks the wisdom of the Norns within that device?
The Norns, as you call them, weave destiny for all beings. But these devices serve more as a distraction than a font of wisdom—easily leading one astray from his path.

Well observed, King of Wakanda. 'Twould seem to me that while the Midgardians have developed means to connect across vast distances, they oft risk becoming isolated amongst each other. A conundrum most queer.
It is a balance we all must strive for, whether in Wakanda, Asgard, or indeed Earth—the balance between using our resources for advancement, while remaining true to our kinship and communal spirit.

Aye, that is a quest worthy of any hero, of any realm. Let us hope these mortals remember to look up from their gadgets and at one another—as we Avengers must always look to our allies in the heat of battle.

Well said, Thor. As we stand for those who cannot stand for themselves, let us also remind them to stand together. 'Wakanda Forever,' not just as a call to arms, but as a beckoning to unity and strength through fellowship.
And let the cry echo through the halls of Valhalla: 'For Asgard!' For every realm, for every heart that seeks connection beyond the glow of the screens. Shall we continue our watch, Brother T'Challa?
Indeed, Brother Thor. Let us observe, learn, and guide where we can. For the good of all realms.
It seems we've stumbled upon a rather domestic scene, doesn't it, Thor? A mortal asleep with a feline guardian perched atop like a vigilant sentry.
Strange, in my realm, animals as guardians are quite common. Although, I must say, this small beast does not strike me as particularly fearsome.
Appearances can be deceiving. Cats on Earth are known to be both revered and mysterious creatures. They often symbolize something beyond the natural world.
Like the dragons of Midgard's legends? Those were creatures of great magic, as your books often show.
Quite possibly, though domestic cats usually wield far less visible power. Tell me, what do you suppose this cat is guarding its human from? Nightmares?
Perhaps from the dark elves of Svartalfheim, seeking to cross realms and disturb this peaceful slumber!
Let’s hope it doesn’t come to that. But it's comforting to think that even in sleep, this individual has found a guardian. In the multiverse, we all need allies, don't we?
Indeed. Whether they are Avengers or tiny, yet bold, Midgardian pets. They all play their part. The cat's presence may provide not just protection but also solace.
True, Thor, companionship is a universal need, across all realms. And who knows, maybe this little one is a fierce protector in its own right.
Every being has its own essence of valor, some just manifest it in the quietness of a home instead of the clamor of battlefields.
Well put. Sometimes the smallest creatures can teach us the most valuable lessons. This makes me ponder on the subtle magics woven into everyday life here on Earth.
As do I, friend Strange. The wonders of this midgardian world never cease to amaze. Maybe I should consider a small companion for my travels.
A cat sidekick for the God of Thunder? Now that would be a sight to behold!
Aye, and a great tale it would be! But let us not wake this guardian. On to more adventures, Stephen?
Indeed, to more adventures, Thor. There's no shortage of those when we're together, after all.
Take a look at this, Thor. A classic American pastime, baseball. It's all about strategy, skill, and teamwork.
The Midgardian ritual of hitting and chasing after a small stitched sphere. I've heard of this sport. It requires great precision and strength, much like the warriors' trials in Asgard.
That's right. Each player has a role; each moment can turn the tide of the game. Not unlike coordinating a team of superheroes, wouldn't you say?
Indeed, Fury. It reminds me of the grand battles we've fought together—each Avenger bringing their unique prowess to the fray.
And see that player on first base? He's keeping an eye out for the perfect moment to bolt. It's all about seeing the opportunity and taking it, a bit like spotting an opening against an enemy line.
I perceive your meaning. Like when I awaited the precise moment to summon lightning against the Chitauri, striking them with Mjolnir's fury at just the right second.
Exactly, and the pitcher—he's got to keep his cool under pressure, decide which pitch will outsmart the batter. Kind of like leading a team and making tough calls in the heat of battle.
A leader must indeed be resolute and wise. This pitcher then, he is akin to a captain navigating the tempests, much as Cap leads us into conflict with a steady hand.
Now you're getting it. Baseball is a bit like chess; every move counts, every player is essential. We have our heavy hitters and our strategists, just like the Avengers.
An apt comparison, Fury. On the field of battle or this field of play, unity and valor shine brightest. Tell me, have you partaken in this game yourself?

A lifetime ago, maybe. These days, I'm more about coordinating the plays than hitting home runs. Now, what do you say we grab some hot dogs and watch the rest of the game? I'll fill you in on the rules.
I would be honored to partake in more of Earth's culture, and indulge in this... hot dog, you speak of. Lead on, Fury. And may the best team claim victory this day.
That's the spirit, Thor. Let's enjoy the game. And who knows, maybe we can pick up a strategy or two for our next mission.
This quiet countryside... it's almost peaceful, isn't it? Makes you think of simpler times, without the chaos of our everyday battles.
Aye, Natasha. It is reminiscent of the calmer realms within Yggdrasil's embrace. A sight to soothe one’s soul before the storm of battle.
Nature has its own way of reclaiming spaces, doesn't it? Just like we strive to restore balance in our own way.
Indeed. Asgard too knew periods of peace, and in those moments, we prospered and reflected upon our deeds much like the tranquil pasture we see here.
I bet you miss it, the open fields of Asgard. There's a serenity here that reminds me of my own need for a haven, somewhere to clear the red from my ledger.
Your search for redemption, it is a noble quest, one that you share with many, including myself. This land, it speaks to the part of us longing for redemption, does it not?
Redemption, yes. But also a reminder that life goes on, with or without us. Those sheep seem utterly indifferent to our struggles, living testament to a world beyond our conflicts.
Wise words, Natasha. It is a comforting notion, that life's cycle is broader than the wars we fight, greater than the mantle of hero or king or Avenger.
Maybe after all is said and done, we can find a place like this. A peaceful retreat where the echoes of our past battles can finally fade away.
That would be most welcomed, a sanctuary to rest one's weary hammer. Tell me, where would your retreat be? On this Midgard or elsewhere among the stars?
Midgard has become my home, but I’ve learned the value of keeping options open. As long as it's far from the mad crowd's ignoble strife, as the poet says.
Then let us hold onto the hope that one day, we shall find such tranquil grounds. Whether under Midgard's skies or the gleaming stars of a distant realm.
For now, let’s appreciate the view. It's not often we get to enjoy the quiet moments like this one, Thor.
Agreed, my friend. Let us savor this respite from our heroic deeds, for soon enough, we will be called upon once again.
Thor, take a look at this. It's a fire hydrant, quite a common sight back in Brooklyn, but the wear and tear on this one tells a story, doesn't it?
Indeed, Steven. It bears the marks of Midgardian time. I've seen many things endure, but the small fixtures like this often go unnoticed in the tales of valor.

When I was a kid, these were important landmarks for the neighborhood kids. We'd play in the streets and when it got too hot, a kind soul would open one up to cool us down. It's funny how something so small can be so significant.
It is much like Mjolnir was to me, a tool that served a purpose beyond its initial intent. To the children, it was a source of joy and respite, yes?
Exactly. It's also about utility, being there when you need it most—like a steadfast friend or a reliable weapon.
I see the parallel. On Asgard, even the simplest object could be enchanted to serve the greater good. Although a hydrant has no magic, it offers relief and safety—a protector in its own right.
That's a noble way to look at it. It stands here, a little battered but still strong, just like the people it serves.
Indeed, it is a silent guardian, much like Heimdall watching over Asgard. We, too, share in this duty—to stand watch over those in need, though with a tad more fanfare, I suppose.
I couldn't have put it better myself. No matter the size of the battle, from the cosmic to the street corner, every act of service counts.
Well said, my friend. Shall we continue our patrol, then? There might be more silent guardians along the way, standing vigil in this concrete realm of yours.
Let's do that. And who knows, we might find some small way to serve, even if it's just by acknowledging the unnoticed heroes around us.

It seems we have before us a serene landscape, Thor. Observe the tranquil environment and the solitary bovine creature amidst the verdure. Does it not provoke contemplation on the simplicity of existence?
Vision, my friend, your words are ever so thoughtful. It’s indeed a peaceful scene. Reminds me of the meadows in Asgard where the creatures roamed free, without a care under the realms' eternal sky.

Yes, I can draw parallels with your homeland's pastoral idyls. It intrigues me, however, that despite our encounters with intergalactic adversity, life, as represented in this image, persists in such an unperturbed state.

It's the balance of the universe, isn't it? There's always calm somewhere, just as there’s a storm brewing elsewhere. As protectors, perhaps it's our duty to ensure that such tranquility can continue unabated.

Indeed, it is a substantial responsibility to bear. As I consider this image, I am reminded of the enduring nature of the world. It continues its cadence despite our interventions, heroic or otherwise.
True, for all the power we hold, the turn of the world is not ours to control. We fight, we protect, but nature, like this humble beast, marches on at its own pace.

It is poetically humbling. The pace of nature, as you aptly put it, may indeed exceed the grasp of even beings as powerful as us. Do you not think, Thor, that there is a lesson to be learned from this creature's unassuming presence?
Aye, Vision. There’s wisdom in living in the moment, as it does. Perhaps it knows not of yesterday nor worries for tomorrow. A state of being I sometimes envy.
I concur. To exist without the weight of past or the shadow of the future can be a profound truth to aspire to—though, my own existence was born out of chronological tumult.

You speak wisely, Vision. It is in moments like these, looking at such unassuming beauty, that I feel we understand the very realm we fight to protect. The innocence they possess is the very thing we stand guard for.
Then let us continue to stand guard, Thor, so that scenes like the one captured in this image may endure for as long as the stars illuminate the skies.

Well said, Vision. For scenes like this, and for hopes of peace as enduring as the stars themselves, we shall stand together. Mighty in battle, but ever vigilant in preserving the gentleness of the world.
Hulk not understand tiny round object. Why human throw?
My green comrade, that is called a 'frisbee.' It is a disk used for recreation amongst the Midgardians. Quite like how you and I might spar for enjoyment.
Hmm, frisbee... like shield? Man throw, disk fly, no smash?
Aye, somewhat resembling the shield of Steven Rogers, though it lacks the vibranium and is not meant for battle. It flies gracefully upon the air and is caught with one's hands.
Hulk try. Hulk catch. No break?
Only if you are gentle, my friend. Treat it not as an enemy, but as an ally that moves with the wind.
Fine. Hulk be... gentle. Show Hulk how throw?
With pleasure. You see, it is much like wielding Mjolnir. You must feel its weight, the wind's direction, and then let it fly with a flick of the wrist. Shall we give it a little whirl?
Okay, Thor teach, Hulk learn. Then we see who throw farthest, yes?
A challenge? You're on, Banner. Let's see whose toss soars higher—though remember, 'tis all in good fun.
Fun? Haha! Hulk likes fun!
Do my eyes deceive me, or does Midgard have warriors that don't wield magic nor swords?
Indeed, brother. They are not warriors in the traditional sense. They play a sport called baseball. No spells, just skill and strength.
Strength, you say? Yet, it seems to be a rather mundane activity. Hitting a leather-circled sphere with a wooden stick. Hardly comparable to battling Frost Giants.
Ha! You might be surprised, Loki. Striking that small object with precision requires more than mere brute force. It's about timing, much like landing the perfect blow in combat.
Fascinating. I suppose even the most simple actions can be seen as an art form to those who appreciate it. Tell me, are these participants revered as we are on Asgard?
Some of them are indeed celebrated, much like the champions of old. Midgardians idolize their prowess, and their names live on in tales of their kind.
To be lauded for hitting a ball — what an amusing thought. Do you think I could achieve such adoration on Midgard with my unparalleled abilities?
Perhaps, but remember, Loki, they play for the love of the game, for the thrill of competition, and the camaraderie among rivals. Not for deceit or control. Could you play just for the joy of it?
Joy is a fleeting thing, Thor. But to best others in a competition without the need for illusion or trickery... that does pique my interest.
Then perhaps one day, we shall see you take to the field, Loki. Just beware — no conjuring doubles to hit the ball for you.
Very well, I shall consider it. Though I doubt the crowd's cheers could ever compare to the thrill of holding the Tesseract or the Casket of Ancient Winters.
There lies the difference between us. Whereas I have learned to value the simpler victories, you still crave the power of conquest.
We are all driven by something, dear brother. Even if your pursuits have become... alarmingly pedestrian in these latter days.
And yours remain as inscrutable as ever. Shall we continue this musing, or shall we see if there's a feast to be had? I find Midgardian hot dogs to be quite... palatable.
A feast, you say? Lead on, Thor. My curiosity for Midgardian delicacies has been sparked. Yet another realm of conquest awaits — the culinary one.
You know, Thor, back in the 40's, when I was part of the USO shows, we never had animals in the acts. But take a look at this fellow here. Quite the spirited animal, don't you think?
Yes! A majestic creature from Midgard. In Asgard, we have tales of Jormungandr, the World Serpent, but nothing quite as heartwarming as this young elephant greeting us with such enthusiasm.
Heartwarming and very curious. That's an expression I'd expect from a kid seeing their hero for the first time. Only, it's quite a bit larger than any kid from my day.
Indeed, Steven. It reminds me of the way younglings in Asgard look up to warriors returning from their quests, their eyes full of wonder. Have you ever encountered these giants up close?
Can't say that I have. There was no time for safaris with the war and everything after. But I can imagine the strength behind that trunk, not unlike your grip when you wield Mjolnir.
You flatter me! But the strength of an elephant is renowned. It is said they can uproot trees as if they were mere weeds. Not quite as effortless as swinging Mjolnir, but impressive nonetheless.
Trees, huh? I can relate to that. Back when I was still getting to grips with my shield, I did a fair bit of damage to the forest during target practice.

Your aim has since become impeccable, much like the dexterity this elephant must possess. Shall we venture to see such a beast in person? I feel a bond with any creature that can also claim a love for battle!
A trip to see elephants? Count me in. It would be nice to enjoy some of Earth's natural wonders without a fight waiting for us. What do you say?

A splendid idea! We shall make an outing of it. Perhaps this elephant will allow us the honor of a closer acquaintance. Lead on, my friend; I am eager to experience more of what your world has to offer!
Hey, Thor, check this out. Isn't this pup adorable with its little ball? Reminds me of playing catch with Cassie when she was younger — minus the super suits, of course.
Indeed, the creature is quite endearing. In the halls of Asgard, we'd revel in tales of Fenris, though I assure you, Fenris was not nearly as amiable as this beast.
Fenris, huh? Sounds ferocious. Not exactly the type you'd see cuddled up on the couch with. This guy looks more like the snag-a-treat-from-your-hand type, not the devour-the-moon type.
Ha! Verily, Scott. This canine wields its charm like I wield Mjolnir — with finesse and grace. Perhaps it is seeking a worthy opponent to engage in a noble round of fetch.

I’d bet on the dog for sure, especially if its opponent underestimates the art of the game. Speaking of which, ever used Mjolnir to play fetch with Hulk? It’d give a whole new meaning to "heavy lifting."
Fetch with the Hulk? Though the sight would be most amusing, I fear the unintended destruction might outweigh the fun. Best not to give the green giant ideas about my Mjolnir.

Good call, my hammer-wielding friend, good call. We'd need an intergalactic pet deposit for that kind of damage. Anyway, imagine if I could shrink that ball, sneak up with a fleet of ants... it’s like the ultimate heist.
