But remember the honor in the straightforward challenge, Scott. Perhaps the pup would appreciate the contest as it stands. After all, heroes, much like our four-legged allies, honor the path of valor.
You've got a point there, Thor. All this talk about pets is kind of making me miss Antony. He might have been an ant, but he had the heart of a lion. Or a particularly brave canine.
Antony was a noble steed indeed. Come, let us find a ball to honor his memory, perhaps brighten the day for this spotted companion before us.
Lead the way, Point Break. Operation: Dog's Day Afternoon is a go!
You know, there's something oddly peaceful about this image. Stuffed animals hanging on a line. Reminds me of simpler times, like when the biggest decision of the day was what toy to play with.

Yes, it does have a tranquil quality to it. Back in Asgard, we had tapestries that held similar scenes but of mythical creatures and valiant battles. Though, I must admit, none were quite as cuddly as these.
Cuddly? If memory serves me, you had a soft spot for that bilgesnipe plush. Don't think I forgot about that little tidbit.
Hahaha! Bilgesnipe are revered creatures, Stark. Ferocious and tenacious. Quite the opposite of these gentle beasts strung up here. But yes, perhaps there is a soft spot in this Asgardian’s heart.
I should design a plush toy line called "Creatures of Asgard." With armor, of course. They'd be a hit at Comic-Con.
And I could see them being popular among the young ones. The tales of Asgard could inspire many, much like how these simple toys likely spark imagination in children.

You're right about that. Toys like these... they kind of inspire creativity. The next Iron Man could be out there right now, his mind churning from staring at a plush dog. Or the next Thor, swinging his mighty...
Plush hammer. Yes, although it would be somewhat less effective in battle, the sentiment is endearing, my friend.
Not everything's about battle, Point Break. Sometimes it's the little things, like making sure you've got the fluffiest bear on the line, not the one that's going to help you take down a Chitauri.
You make a fair point, Man of Iron. It is in the small moments of joy and warmth we find much of life's worth. Though, speaking of small things, have you seen Dr. Banner's "figurine" collection?

Bruce and his action figures. The guy's got taste—I'll give him that. But yeah, let's just keep the fact that we discussed teddy bears between us, okay? Heaven forbid Cap hears about this and thinks we've gone soft.
Agreed. The Son of Rogers has no need to know about our musings. And Stark, soft or not, your heart has always been your greatest strength—even when clad in iron.
This scene, it's almost serene, isn't it? A simplicity I haven't felt in a long while. A part of me envies their ordinary lives.
Indeed, Wanda. The mortals bask unaware in the gentle embrace of Midgard, free from burdens of cosmic consequence. It does seem peaceful.
To think that such tranquility exists, it almost seems like a different reality. One where chaos magic bears no sway.
But remember that tranquility dwells within as much as without. Even we, wielders of mighty powers, can find solace in moments such as these. This is the gift of Midgard – it teaches us humility.
Yet, our destinies appear forever entwined with the greater machinations of the universe. I suppose, though, that moments like these are what we fight for – the simple pleasures of life.

Aye, that is the very essence of heroism, to fight for the chance of peace, not just for us but for all beings. Whether it be on Asgard or Sokovia, the sands of time never cease their flow within realms of gods or men. We, too, can appreciate the rhythm of these quieter waves.
It is... reassuring, in a way, to witness life's persistence, persistence in spite of the chaos we've faced. To know there is still beauty, still light.
Well spoken, Scarlet Witch. After the storms we have weathered, we know the importance of seeking the calm after. Even the thunder god relishes the stillness that follows the tempest.
I suppose every spell I cast, every weave of magic is, in a way, seeking this balance. Perhaps one day, that serenity will no longer be a distant dream.

And on that day, should you wish it, the shores of Midgard will welcome you, as they have welcomed this unworthy god before. Now, come, let us enjoy this moment, for tomorrow is another battle yet to be fought.
A small human engaging with the tide, a battle against the inevitable flow. Do you not see, Thor? Even the simplest of exercises is a struggle against nature's overwhelming force.

I see a child of Midgard embracing the challenge, Thanos. The surf underfoot, the salt air – it is joy in the face of the mighty sea. It's a testament to the resilience of living beings, not a struggle.

Resilience? Or a futile refusal to accept the fundamental laws of the universe? Order and balance are what sustain life, yet here they are, pitting their mortality against the endless surge of the ocean.

You misunderstand the heart of mortals. It's not a rejection of nature's laws, but a celebration of them. Look at her stance, the concentration, the mastery of balance – this is not a battle, but a dance with the elements.
Perhaps there is merit to your perspective, God of Thunder. It is not often I consider such trivial pastimes. But mastery of balance, you say? In that, we can find common ground.
Aye, Thanos. We seem to cherish balance, though your method seeks to snuff out the flame of life while mine strives to keep it kindling.
And therein lies the difference between us, Asgardian. I take the necessary steps for the good of the many, while you hold onto the naive hope for each soul.

And I will continue to do so. As long as there is breath in my body, I shall defend the right of each soul to find joy, to surf the waves of their existence. It is a far nobler aim than yours, Mad Titan.
Noble? Perhaps. But inevitability cares not for nobility. The universe's scales must be balanced, by will... or by destiny.
Let destiny try, I say. As long as there are beings who love life, who fight for the beauty of their short-lived sparks, there will be heroes who stand against the darkness of your ideology, Thanos.
We shall see, Thunderer. For now, let us watch the rhythm of the tides and the fleeting, joyous defiance of your mortal surfers.
You know, Thor, I've seen a lot in my time – aliens, killer robots, a guy who's practically a talking tree – but I still find something oddly relatable about this bear just chilling here.
Yes, the Midgardian creature known as the 'bear'. Mighty beasts of your realm. Reminds me of the great wolves of Asgard, lounging after feasting in the dining halls of Valhalla.
Speaking of lounging, doesn't this picture just scream 'I've saved the world and now I take my well-deserved break'? I mean, that's the kind of vacation I could get on board with.
To rest like the bear, one must first fight valiantly like the bear. I can see the weariness in the beast's eyes, the same that was once in ours after battle.
And yet, here he is without a care in the world. Tony Stark could learn a thing or two from this bear. Maybe spend a little less time in the suit and more time in the sun.
Indeed, Stark. Even gods must find time for quietude and reflection amid the storms. This bear, he understands balance, it seems.
Balance, sure. But I've got to hand it to him for choosing the best spot to kick back. Raise your hand if you’ve saved the universe and earned a nap... Oh, wait, we'd both raise our hands.
Ha! Aye, Iron Man, let us both take a moment of silence for our triumphs then. And perhaps, when we are done safeguarding the realms once again, we can retire to such a peaceful existence.
I'll drink to that, Point Break. But let's be honest, peace is fleeting, especially with our track record. Until the next apocalyptic event, let's just enjoy the stillness.
Agreed, friend Stark. And should we ever grow fatigued, we shall look upon this bear and be reminded that even the fiercest warriors can afford a moment of peace.
Take a look at this, Thor. No high-tech armor, no mythical hammer, just a small creature of Earth. Yet it survives through the chaos.
Indeed, Director Fury. On Midgard, there are such delicate beings. But even the sparrow knows the skies and their place within them.
You might have a thing or two to learn from it then. It's got wings but spends plenty of time grounded. Knowing when to fly and when to stay put; that's strategy.
Aye, there is a wisdom in picking one's battles, just as the sparrow chooses when it must take to wing. But tell me, Fury, why do you think this creature merits our attention?
Everything on this Earth has its role, Thor. No matter how small, it matters. I like to remember that when we're making plans that shake the world.
An observation most keen. I too have learned that every soul plays a part in the tapestry of the cosmos – from the humblest man of Midgard to the mightiest of Asgard.
Tell me, Thor, in your vast travels, have you seen creatures like this elsewhere? Or is this a unique spectacle to our little corner of the universe?
The realms do indeed hold wonders beyond count. Yet, I must confess, the life that thrives on Midgard has a charm unlike any other. Each beast and bird, unique in voice and spirit.
Couldn't agree more. We've got our work cut out for us to keep them safe. And that includes even these little birds.
As long as the breath of life fills my chest, I shall raise hammer and heart to protect this planet and livings beings as gentle as this sparrow.
Good to know we can count on you, Thor. As long as we've got defenders like you, Earth's got a fighting chance.
Hey, Thor, check this out. I can't help but think that crow over there is plotting something sinister. You ever get the feeling animals are more aware than they let on?

Aye, my small companion, in the realms of Asgard we speak often of animals possessing a wisdom beyond our ken. That crow, perhaps it is Huginn or Muninn in disguise, keeping watch over the Earthly realms.
Huginn or who-now? Are those friends of yours?
Huginn and Muninn, my friend. They are the ravens of Odin Allfather, sent out each morning to fly about the world, and upon their return, they report the news of the world to him.

Wow, see, now that's surveillance I can get behind. No tech, no fancy gadgets, just good old-fashioned bird watching. Although, if they can report news, those birds are probably smarter than half my old heist crew.
Ha! Indeed, Scott of Lang. But tell me, dost thou see something amiss within this earthly scene?

Well, aside from our feathered friend here, it's looking a bit like someone dashed off in a hurry. Check out that trash. You know, I used to not think much about a little litter, but Cassie, she's big on the environment. Makes you want to take better care of the world, you know?

Verily, the little ones do teach us the importance of stewardship. As a king, I was tasked with the protection of realms, but oft it's the smaller acts that pave the way for grandeur. Perhaps we should take it upon ourselves to tend to this neglected piece of Midgard.

Yeah, I'm with you. It might not be as epic as saving the universe, but hey, every little bit counts, right? Plus, with our powers combined, we'll make quick work of this. I can shrink down, get into those tiny places, and...
And I shall summon a gentle breeze with Mjolnir to whisk away these foul remnants. Let us join forces, Ant-Man!
I can't shake off this feeling like we're about to be ambushed while picking up trash, though. Too many action sequences on the brain, I guess. But yeah, let's do this, Thunder Buddy!
Ha! Fear not, we shall keep one another safe from ambush, whether it be from an enemy or a rogue soda can. Onward, to glorious tidying!
To glorious tidying! Not the battle cry I imagined for us, but hey, it's got a nice ring to it.
Look at human. Sitting in snow, no moving. Why sit there?
My green comrade, it appears the mortal is indulging in what they call 'snowboarding,' a sport of sorts.
Sport? Hulk likes sports. Is like fight?

Not quite like the battle you revel in, Hulk. 'Tis a dance with nature, a challenge against the slippery slopes of frost and ice. He seems to have taken a tumble, though, judging by the snow around him.
He stuck? Hulk can help! Hulk good at smashing... and helping!
Nay, friend Hulk, he does not confront peril. Humans often enjoy the snow in this manner, and the pose he strikes suggests he may yet rise again with a laugh.
Human not strong like Hulk. Hulk not like cold. Cold makes Hulk... shiver.

Fear not, for the cold I hail from in Asgard's winters would make this mere earth-chill seem like a warm breeze. The mortal is clad in layers to stave off the cold. Much like the armor we don for combat.
Hulk think... maybe fun? Hulk try?
Should you wish to trade your smashing for sliding, I would pay good coin to see such an event. The image of you on a snowboard would be one for the ages.
Hulk not need board, have feet. Hulk slide on feet!
A spectacle truly magnificent to imagine! But perhaps we should leave such adventures to those less... Hulk-sized.
Fine. Hulk not slide. Hulk watch. Maybe Hulk laugh if human fall again.
That’s the spirit. Laughter in the face of a fall is a fine thing. It lifts the spirits like a well-told tale or a triumphant victory.
Victory good. Hulk like victory. Next time, human should smash snow. Show who boss.
Perhaps, but there is victory in rising after a fall as well. Each time this human stands, it is in its own way, a triumph.
Hm, Hulk understand. Fall, then rise. Like fight. Hulk does that. Hulk always rises.
Indeed you do, mighty Hulk. Indeed you do. Now, let us see if our snow-bound friend here will do the same.
